bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Arthur W. Packard, October 29, 1947

div1.p: Hench requests a meeting with Packard in New York. He relates the story of his yellow fever research, the discovery of Camp Lazear Building No. 1, and subsequent efforts to memorialize the site. He seeks the financial support of the Rockefeller Foundation, explaining that the Cubans feel Finlay was denied credit for his yellow fever work and blame the Rockefeller Foundation, in part, for championing Reed over Finlay. Hench believes this is an opportunity to recognize the work of both Finlay and the Americans.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Arthur W. Packard, October 29, 1947
div1.opener:
October 29, 1947
Mr. Arthur W. Packard
49 West 49th Street
New York, New York
My dear Mr. Packard:
div1.p:
Would it be possible for me to have an interview with you in New
York City, if you are to be there, Tuesday, November 18? I enclose a letter
of introduction written for me by Dr. Wilbur A. Sawyer last July when I had
expected to come to New York to see you but was unable to do so.

Let me state frankly the purpose of my interview. Some years ago
as a hobby I took up the story of the conquest of yellow fever of Walter Reed
and his associates. This led me to several visits to Cuba and many trips
around the country interviewing the survivors of these illustrious experi-
ments and I uncovered many new facts and also found a mountain of old letters,
documents, etc., pertaining to the experiments and to the participants. These
contain much unpublished and important material.

On one of my early visits to Cuba, I made a sentimental journey to
the supposed site of Camp Lazear, the little experimental camp where Reed
carried on the concluding experiments, which site had been eroneously located
and marked by the Cuban Government. To make a long story short, with help
from others, I was able to locate the actual camp site and mirabile dictu,
we found the remains of the original little “Building Number One” made so
famous by Walter Reed. I took preliminary steps to preserve the little
building and have had some correspondence and visits with the Cuban officials
with the aim of preserving the building permanently and enclosing it in a
modest “Cuban-American museum” in memory of the conquerors of yellow fever,
Finlay as well as the Americans. This project has been received with en-
thusiasm by the Cubans and they have just made the little shack a national
monument; however, their support has been more vocal than monetary.

The Mayo Foundation has promised me a significant contribution
toward this little project. Because of the long-continued and present
interest of the Rockefeller Foundation in the conquest and control of yellow
fever, I believe or at least hope, that some members of the Rockefeller family
might join with the Mayo Foundation and with me personally in raising a modest
fund for the purpose mentioned. Appropriately, two years from now will occur
the 50th anniversary of the conquest of yellow fever. In my preliminary con-
versations with Cuban government officials, including the President of Cuba,
they assured me that they would be delighted to join in the venture and make
the dedication of such a memorial a Cuban-American international affair.

Unfortunately, the war and my entrance into military service interrupted
almost entirely my efforts along the lines mentioned and only recently have I
been able to take up the matter again. You may or may not be aware of the
fact that many Cuban physicians and government officials believe that Finlay
their great scientist, was robbed of most of his fame by the protagonists
of Reed and I must tell you that in certain quarters, some of the early ap-
proval of Reed by the Rockefeller FoundationIwas considered a strong factor
in depriving Finlay of “his just deserts”. This most unhappy anti-Reed and
anti-U. S. Yellow Fever Board sentiment in Cuba could, I believe, be largely
done away with were we able to conclude the project. This little building
and the remains of Camp Lazear represent the one remaining concrete historical
“souvenir” of one of the great contributions of medical science.

I would appreciate it greatly if you would give me the little time
necessary to show you photographs of the remains of the little building, a
little documentary proof of its validity and a very few other important items.
Should you wish me to send ahead some of this data, I shall be glad indeed to
do so. In lieu of this, I am sending you a reprint of an article of mine pub-
lished in Hygeia, a few years ago.

Let me assure you, Mr. Packard, I have no personal ax to grind in
this matter. I have spent a considerable amount of my own funds and had a
lot of fun doing it. I have myself contributed the first $1,000 towards our
little fund. I have many personal friends in New York who will vouch for
me should you wish me to name them.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, Philip S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
